course_title: Special Topics: American Questions: Found of Amer Society to 1877

class_notes:
(Same as HIST 285 1)
(Considers the development of American society from its beginnings through Reconstruction. Special emphasis is given to certain critical periods including the British colonial era, the American Revolution, and the Civil War.
This course introduces students to central themes, issues, events, and personalities in early American history. Focusing on central issues in the social, cultural, and political history, it is driven by two guiding assumptions: that an informed awareness of the present begins with a responsible and sophisticated awareness of the past; and that gaining a sophisticated awareness of early American history provides important insight into the American story as a whole.)
Required Texts:
James L.Roark, Michael P. Johnson, et al, The American Promise: A History of the United States, vol. I: to 1877. ISBN: 0312452926.
Frederick Douglass, Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass: An American Slave, edited by David W. Blight. ISBN: 978-0-312-25737-6.
Harriet Beecher Stowe, Uncle Tom's Cabin. ISBN: 978-04486440286
Sean Wilentz and Paul Johnson, The Kingdom of Matthias. ISBN: 978-0199892495
Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin. ISBN: 978-1936594092
Bernard Bailyn, Origin of American Politics. ISBN: 978-0394708652.
Grading based on:
Midterm Examination: Take-home essay	
Final Examination: Take-home.	
Participation in weekly discussions
